title: 108_hr2061
content: The Act is titled the "National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Reauthorization Act of 2003" and includes general improvements to the National Anti-Drug Media Campaign. The Drug-Free Media Campaign Act of 1998 is amended to the National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act, focusing on preventing drug abuse among young people. The National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act aims to prevent drug abuse among young people in the United States by increasing awareness and encouraging discussions about the dangers of drug use among parents and adults. The National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act empowers the Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug Free America, to determine the overall purposes and strategy of the national media campaign. The Director is responsible for implementing a focused national media campaign to meet the Act's purposes. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug-Free America, approves the strategy, advertising, and plan for the national media campaign. The Partnership recommends strategies to achieve the campaign's goals. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug-Free America, requests strategies for the national media campaign to address drug threats at national, regional, and local levels. The Partnership creates advertising for the campaign, excluding ads from other nonprofit entities. The Partnership for a Drug-Free America creates advertising for a national media campaign to address drug threats, excluding ads from other nonprofit entities. Ads must be intended for minority, ethnic, or special audiences that cannot be obtained at no cost, and any other ads the Partnership determines it cannot provide. Ads are tested before release. The Partnership for a Drug-Free America creates advertising for a national media campaign to address drug threats, excluding ads from other nonprofit entities. Ads must be intended for minority, ethnic, or special audiences that cannot be obtained at no cost, and any other ads the Partnership determines it cannot provide. Ads are tested before release. The Director enters into a contract with a media buying contractor to plan and purchase advertising time and space for the national media campaign. The Partnership for a Drug-Free America contracts a media buying contractor to plan and purchase advertising time and space for the national media campaign, including strategic planning and accounting for purchases. The Partnership for a Drug-Free America contracts a media buying contractor to plan and purchase advertising time and space for the national media campaign, including strategic planning and accounting for purchases. In subparagraph (C), "out-of-pocket" is removed, and in subparagraph (F), "the Office of National Drug Control Policy" is replaced with "either the Office of National Drug Control Policy or the designee of the Office." Paragraph (2) is replaced with new provisions on advertising. The Director must allocate sufficient funds for the national media campaign's goals, with an exception for creative development of advertisements unless targeting minority or special populations. The Director must allocate funds for national media campaigns targeting minority or special populations, with prior notice to the Committees on Appropriations. The Committees on Appropriations of the House and Senate, the Committee on Government Reform of the House of Representatives, and the Committee on the Judiciary of the Senate are involved in making amendments to subsections and matching requirements for allocated funds. The national media campaign under section 106 requires a no cost match of equivalent value of advertising broadcast time or in-kind contributions before the Director can purchase advertising time or space. The Director must ensure that all no cost matches or in-kind contributions for advertising material directly relate to substance abuse prevention. Advertising material donated at no cost is exempt from sponsorship identification provisions. The Director must ensure that at least 85% of funds appropriated for the national media campaign are used for advertising time and space, with a cap of $5,000,000 for other expenses. The national media campaign funds must primarily be used for advertising time and space, with a limit of $5,000,000 for other expenses. SEC. 104. FINANCIAL AND PERFORMANCE ACCOUNTABILITY. The Director is required to conduct audits of records and costs, as well as appoint an independent entity to assess the effectiveness of the national media campaign based on data from the 'Monitoring the Future Study' by the Department of Health and Human Services. The Director must gather data from various studies, including the `Monitoring the Future Study' and the National Household Survey on Drug Abuse, to submit a report to Congress. The Director must gather evaluation data according to industry standards and submit a report to Congress as per section 105. The Director must gather evaluation data according to industry standards and submit a report to Congress as per section 105. The Director must submit an annual report to Congress detailing the national media campaign strategy, objectives achieved, operational efficiency, advertising plans, and measures to prevent misuse of Federal funds. Federal funds are responsibly used for advertising to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse, including contracts with media campaign entities. Authorization of $195,000,000 for the Office of National Drug Control Policy for fiscal years 2004 through 2008.
